It may be interesting to compare this Ko Shoami piece:

http://tinyurl.com/jnpn8

and this Kyo Shoami:

http://www.zincavage.org/DeerandMaple.html

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: klepet33319 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Friday, April 21, 2006 1:58 PM
  Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: in defense of the ugly bird or seeking more " punishment "


  The scan I posted earlier was from that book -- B/W.

  --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "David Zincavage" <jdz@...> 
  wrote:
  >
  > A good photo presumably also appears in:
  > 
  > Japanese Sword-fittings & metalwork in the LUNDGREN COLLECTION, 
  Tokyo: Otsuka Kogeisha, 1992  
  > 
  > I'm not, at the moment, able to locate my copy. 
  >   ----- Original Message ----- 
  >   From: klepet33319 
  >   To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  >   Sent: Friday, April 21, 2006 10:32 AM
  >   Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: in defense of the ugly bird or 
  seeking more " punishment "
  > 
  > 
  >   David -- would you be so kind to give me the information for the 
  >   catalog that picture came from?  Thanks much.
  >   Pete Klein
  > 
  > 
  >   --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "David Zincavage" <jdz@> 
  >   wrote:
  >   >
  >   > Before we start discussing it, here is a good picture from the 
  1977 
  >   Christie's Lndgren Sal catalogue:
  >   > 
  >   > http://zincavage.org/KoKinkoKasugane.htm
  >   > 
  >   > 
  >   >   ----- Original Message ----- 
  >   >   From: Barry Thomas 
  >   >   To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  >   >   Sent: Monday, April 17, 2006 12:13 PM
  >   >   Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: in defense of the ugly bird 
  or 
  >   seeking more " punishment "
  >   > 
  >   > 
  >   >   I have followed this discussion with great interest and will 
  have 
  >   to go over it
  >   >   again I'm sure, but I clearly see what Milt is talking 
  about.  To 
  >   find a stiffer
  >   >   deer one would have to go to the tundra...
  >   > 
  >   >   I recall well a tsuba that I found many years ago.  It was a 
  >   small, copper
  >   >   sanmai awase (if I correctly remember a phrase I haven't 
  uttered 
  >   for 15 or more
  >   >   years!) with a touch of silver (tin??) showing stylised 
  >   (stamped?) waves with a
  >   >   creature on it that I always thought was an "over-endowed 
  >   rabbit", but Bob
  >   >   Haynes told me was a fox!!  I wrote to Bob when I saw a 
  similar 
  >   tsuba in one of
  >   >   his catalogues.  I was amazed when he said this was a very 
  early 
  >   style of tsuba
  >   >   ca 1300 - 1400.  I had it for years, often looking at it and 
  >   saying "Do I like
  >   >   it, or do I not??"  Same thing with this deer kinko.  I have 
  >   gazed at Pete
  >   >   Klein's image on yahoo (I actually have the Lundren 
  Collection 
  >   book, but it's
  >   >   out on loan to a 'kinko' mate) for a long time on this 
  sleepless 
  >   night, and I
  >   >   ask myself the same question all over again.  So David Z, if 
  I 
  >   could ask you a
  >   >   question, when you say "I don't collect kinko at all,  but 
  this 
  >   is one of a
  >   >   small number of cases which, granted a opportunity, would 
  lead me 
  >   to alter my
  >   >   policy" I have to ask you "WHY??"  Please explain.
  >   > 
  >   >   If I found this very tsuba I would think it was junk.  I 
  don't 
  >   have to tell you
  >   >   why.  Or do I??  The design spilling into the seppadai I have 
  >   only seen on tsuba
  >   >   I didn't care for.  The wobbly surface and incredibly bad 
  nanako 
  >   would kill it
  >   >   for me.  And the stiff deer doesn't do anything for me at 
  all.  
  >   However, I would
  >   >   look at the larger than usual kozuka ana and opine "Hmmm, 
  maybe 
  >   it's early".
  >   >   Back to my question to myself "Do I like it, or do I not".  
  If I 
  >   don't like it,
  >   >   I don't collect it, no matter what the aesthetes say.
  >   > 
  >   >   Now, this puts me into the rustic class, I know, but there is 
  a 
  >   point to this
  >   >   that is not all derisory or derogatory.  It is this.  It is 
  easy 
  >   to pick
  >   >   excellent work amongst Edo period tsuba , even in the 
  iron "wabi-
  >   sabi" class,
  >   >   but the archaic styles, the transition between (if we might 
  say) 
  >   conceptual
  >   >   forerunners and the refined later schools is much, much more 
  >   difficult.  Or is
  >   >   it??  Recall here Milt's hawk tsuba that lead to the present 
  >   discussion.  And I
  >   >   can show you a tsuba that a well-educated (tsuba knowledge) 
  mate 
  >   of mine
  >   >   dismissed as "late, possibly 1920s".  It is a masterwork of 
  late 
  >   Edo/early Meiji
  >   >   and belongs to a friend of mine.  If he gives permission I'll 
  put 
  >   up some images
  >   >   of it.
  >   > 
  >   >   So, to bring this to a close, are there any others inhabiting 
  the 
  >   same closet as
  >   >   I???  I know I'm lacking an ability, an aesthetic if you 
  like, to 
  >   appreciate the
  >   >   stiff deer kinko in question and it worries me.  It seems 
  without 
  >   thorough study
  >   >   and training many tsuba in this time frame would indeed be 
  >   considered junk and
  >   >   sold off, possibly to an ignominious fate.  The other kinko 
  that 
  >   Pete shows in
  >   >   two images at the same link does "speak to me".  It is from 
  the 
  >   same time frame
  >   >   and I find it elegant and refined and would collect it.  I 
  think 
  >   this discussion
  >   >   parallels the Sue Koto kazuuchimono line of thinking with 
  blades -
  >   I don't
  >   >   collect those either...
  >   > 
  >   >   Barry Thomas
  >   >   (Melbourne, Australia)
  >   >
